data.title: Consider renaming Preferences > Keymaps to Keymap Extensions
data.body:
As a user, I may not understand the difference between Preferences > Keyboard Shortcuts and Keymaps.
Calling out that Keymaps is really Keymap Extensions makes it clear that it isn't an in-product setting and they will be using an extension.
This also helps clarify what a "Keymap" is since the term doesn't exist except as a VS Code extension category.

data.title: Feature request: Add "preLaunchCommand" to launch configuration
data.body:
In addition "preLaunchTask," it would be useful to have the ability to run a command (in my case from an existing extension) before launching a debug session. 
This can possibly be done with the addition of a "preLaunchCommand : command" pair to launch.json.

data.title: 'expandLineSelection' selects extra line when used on an empty line.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enter the following in a text file:
```
foo

bar
baz
```
2. Move cursor to the empty line (line 2).
3. Press `ctrl+i` to invoke `expandLineSelection` command.
4. The empty line and the line containing 'bar' is selected (I would expect only the empty line to be selected).

Note, if you have multiple empty lines, you can continuously select the empty lines one at a time, but once the cursor reaches the last empty line, the next time you press `ctrl+i`, you'll select both the empty line and the next non-empty line as well.

data.title: Allow to hide entries from activity bar
Parallelize text search
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15384#issuecomment-262605055, comment is updated with final timings.

This PR rearranges the existing text search code to run using multiple processes. This doesn't include work to show results sooner - users still need to wait for a batch of 512 file matches to be filled. That work is tracked in Microsoft/vscode#16284. Here's a brain dump for posterity -

RawSearchService creates an instance of textSearch.Engine and passes it a FileWalker which is producing paths in the workspace. This is the same.

textSearch.Engine creates some number of Search Worker processes. The number is determined by `require('os').cpus().length` which returns 8 on a MBP, because it has 4 physical cores, with hyperthreading.

The fileWalker produces file paths, and the sizes in bytes of those files. They are grouped into batches of roughly equal sizes in bytes. The number of files in each batch may vary a lot, but each batch should represent files that are cumulatively about 1MB in size. Hopefully this will make them more likely to be processed in a similar amount of time, with a similar number of results, so one process isn't running for much longer than others. This might sound like a large batch - smaller workspaces won't benefit much from parallelization - but they don't need it. I did some testing on a few workspaces of different sizes with different batch sizes, and 1MB seemed like the sweet spot. I also experimented with a batch size that starts small and grows exponentially, thinking it might help on medium-sized workspaces, but it didn't seem to make a difference.

Batches are sent to the worker as soon as they're ready, in a round-robin fashion. I experimented with sending one batch at a time to each process, with another when it's finished, but that was slower because the worker isn't doing anything while it's waiting for a new batch. I also tried sending a couple batches up front, and more as needed, but it was no better than sending them ASAP. Looking at timings, I think this is because the workers are slow to handle the first couple batches they receive - the fileWalker is actually often done by the time the workers are sending back their first batch of results. I need to investigate more to figure out why this is - maybe because the new processes are still loading code, JITting, etc. They process the rest of the batches much faster after those first few. It may be faster to keep the worker processes around between searches, but I don't know that we want to persist 8 (or more) processes per vscode window.

The worker searches the files using the same code that we already had, this hasn't changed much. It does include the change to eliminate Buffer.slice calls that is already checked in. The only change is that I limited the number of files that it will open at a time, because I kept running into the OS open file limit without it.

The batch includes the current `maxResults`, i.e. the initial max minus the number of results received so far. The main process might receive more than the max number of results from workers, so it has to trim the result set. This is kind of annoying to get exactly right, because the result set is not a flat list, but a tree of files with matches, lines in those files with matches, and the matches on each line. So, it will just take batches until the total is greater than the max. It can go over the max, but this is much easier.

data.title: Sometimes opening file replaces most recent opened file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11..6

Steps to Reproduce:

Code does this only intermittently but it's very annoying when it does happen:

1. have one or more files open for editing
2. open another document by doing one of following: A) Explorer bar, B) QuickOpen, or C) CMD+Click on c# class in current document, the new document replaces the current document. I would expect it to always open the document in a new tab

data.title: Improve batching between search process and frontend
data.body:
Fork of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15384

> The time from starting the search to finding a match is very short, but then we sit on that match for 100+ seconds, because we don't send results to the frontend until we've filled a batch of 512. Since there are fewer than a full batch of results, nothing is visible until the search is over. So we could increase the perceived performance quite a lot by adding a timeout to send intermediate results over if the batch doesn't fill up.

data.title: Typescript syntax highlighting failing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
Not sure as of yet.

When turning on `typescript.tsserver.trace` to true I get the following error:

`[Trace - 11:46:51 AM] Response received: quickinfo (27). Request took 4 ms. Success: false . Message: Error processing request. Project '/Users/amamut/Projects/gambit/tsconfig.json' does not contain document '/users/amamut/projects/gambit/typings/globals/angular/index.d.ts'`

I can say right now that the file in question definitely exists in `'/Users/amamut/Projects/gambit/typings/globals/angular/index.d.ts'`. Notice how in the message the directory is lowercased. I am not sure if that is what is causing the issue but after updating to 1.7.2 my highlighting broke. I will continue to debug and see if I can find more information. I was just hoping someone ran into this problem and was able to remedy.

My tsconfig's include property:
`"include": [
    "src/**/*.ts",
    "typings/**/*.d.ts"
  ]`

Thanks!

data.title: C/C++ syntax highlighting inconsistency.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: 10.11.6 (El Capitan)

### Example problem:

![screen shot 2016-11-30 at 12 17 13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1908886/20763186/fe1b04ec-b6f6-11e6-9839-ae50a28558bb.png)

### Steps to Reproduce:

Effectively, if you copy and paste the following code into your editor, keeping the leading spacing intact.

```
    #define FOO(x)

    FOO(1)

    #undef FOO
```

If you undo the leading spacing, the highlighting works as expected.

This problem only seems to occur if a macro with parameters is in use (i.e. ` FOO(x)`).

In other words, this works fine:
```
    #define FOO

    FOO

    #undef FOO
```

data.title: Alert messages covering the tab bar is just a bad idea
data.body:
I've been trying to switch to VS Code for a while, but one single annoyance makes me stop using it: any kind of error or informational message covers the tab bar, making me unable to do anything unless I dismiss it.  This could be a plugin announcing a new feature, or a plugin announcing that there is a warning.  For example, Unity projects always announce warnings when they build, so for every build, the tabs hide behind a message.

One possible solution: an icon appears in the status bar when errors appear. Clicking on it shows them. Clicking outside hides them. 

- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:01:10.756Z)

data.title: Feature request: Allow grouping of items in the QuickPick input just like the git branches view

It would be nice to allow grouping of QuickPickItems.
Currently one can see this in the `git checkout` branch list. There are the local and the remote branches grouped and separated with a small line.

data.title: Adopt latest Marketplace CDN changes
data.body: Fixes #15557

data.title: Display Set elements in debugger views
data.body:
The elements added to a Set are not displayed in the debugger.

- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Linux x64
- launch: node2
- node: 6.3.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a `new Set()` variable and add some elements to it.
2. View/Expand the variable in Locals/Watches or hover over variable.
3. Only the set size is displayed - none of the actual elements in the set are shown.

Evaluating Maps and Sets don't display anything other than the size. It would be nice to see what elements have been added.

![vscode-set](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13035517/20766124/0b8794a2-b72d-11e6-90d8-44f70141899c.jpg)


A workaround to view the elements is to add a watch of the variable, converting the Set to an array using the spread operator: `[...aSetVariable]`

2. press & left click somewhere in the document
3. drag down

What I would expect is a cursor on every line I dragged pass.

data.title: Enhance configuration edit service to write to buffer
data.body: Currently configuration editing service is directly writing to disk. This will not give Undo capability. Actions in Settings editors are using this editing service to write configurations. So, enhance this service to write to buffer if asked.
